Why Ladakh is home for photographer?
Ladakh, a region in the northern part of India, has become a beloved destination for photographers for several reasons:

Stunning Landscapes: Ladakh is renowned for its breathtaking landscapes, characterized by high-altitude deserts, majestic Himalayan mountains, serene lakes (like Pangong Tso and Tso Moriri), and picturesque valleys. The play of light and shadows against these terrains offers incredible opportunities for landscape photography.

Unique Culture and People: The region is rich in culture, with a blend of Tibetan and Indian influences. Photographers find the traditional clothing, vibrant festivals (like Hemis Festival), and the faces of the Ladakhi people fascinating subjects for capturing cultural diversity.

Varied Climate and Seasons: Ladakh experiences extreme weather conditions, from freezing winters to relatively mild summers. This diversity allows photographers to capture varied landscapes and changing moods throughout the year.

Astrophotography: The high altitude, clear skies, and minimal light pollution make Ladakh an ideal location for astrophotography. Photographers can capture stunning images of the night sky, including the Milky Way and celestial bodies.

Challenging Terrain: The rugged and challenging terrain presents a unique opportunity for adventure and exploration, attracting photographers looking for offbeat locations and unique perspectives.

Spiritual and Heritages Sites: Ladakh is home to numerous ancient monasteries (like Hemis, Thiksey, and Diskit) that not only hold spiritual significance but also offer incredible architectural beauty and historical value, making them prime subjects for photography.
Wild life and Birding: Despite its high-altitude desert landscape, Ladakh hosts a surprising diversity of wildlife and bird species adapted to the harsh conditions.

In essence, Ladakh's combination of stunning natural beauty, unique culture, and diverse landscapes make it a paradise for photographers seeking to capture both the grandeur of nature and the richness of human heritage.

dayInfo.description: Leh arrival: Feel the cool breeze as you arrive at Kushok Bakula Airport Leh 3500m. Our representative shall receive you at the airport and then transferred to hotel. Full day at rest at your hotel room to acclimatize to the altitude of Ladakh which is must. At your Hotel for lunch and later in the afternoon visit Shanti stupa which offers the best aerial views of Leh town and the 16thcentury built former palace of the Kings of Ladakh i.e. Lehchen Palkhar or Leh Palace. Evening a brisk walk to stretch your body. Overnight at the hotel.

Today we shall take you for a fullday tour of some of the most important and beautiful Monasteries and Palaces on the Indus Valley. Visit Thakthok monastery, Stakna and meet Rinpoche, later we drive back to Leh

On the Way visit Spithub monastery, Pather Sahib Sikh Gurduwara, enjoy the view of the confluence of Indus and Zanskar rivers, Basgo castle, Likir monastery and check in hotel in Alchi,check in hotel. Visit Alchi monastery known for the 11th century wall mural and arts.

Alchi to Kargil On the way visit Rizong monastery and its nunnery centre, visit Lamayuru monastery, enjoy the landscape at Lamayuru which is known as the lunar landscape. Visit Mulbik rock carving Buddha and later we reached at Kargil. Check in hotel.

Kargil to Ragdum Kargil to Rangdum we will drive along the Suru valley enjoy the breath taking view of the Nun Kun range and we will visit Kartsey Chamba, the giant Buddha statue of the 3rd century BC, later we reach at Rangdum and overnight stay at camp or Home stay.

Rangdum to Padum via Dzongkhul After breakfast we visist Rangdum monastery and cross Pantsey la pass and enter the beautiful valley of Zanskar valley, enjoy the beautiful mountain ranges of Z3 and Darang Durung Glacier, Drive along the panoramic landscape valley, you will find many small villages of Zanskar with barley crop and pasture land of the valley. We will visit Dzongkhul monastery a small solitary monastery once the meditation cave of Lama Naropa. We check in hotel in Padum.
Around Padum Visit Zangla village and its ruined castle and the landscape, Explore Stongday monastery, and enjoy the panoramic view of the Zanskar region. Later we drive back to Padum

Padum to Phuktal around 80 kms On the way visit Bardan monastery, Money, short hike to Phuktal visit the monastery and back to Purney, check in local home stay. 31st July Day 10 Phuktal to Jispa via Shinkula Drive early morning to Gonbo Rangjon, spend time and tea break around Gonbo Rangjon, cross Shinkun la pass, drive along the Zanskar Sumdo valley and reach at Jispa in the evening
